columnsModelsData Library Report ModelReport ModelAPI docs by RedoclyEntities Reports API (1.0.1)Download OpenAPI specification:DownloadIntroductionThe Entities Reports API is the developer interface for Diligent Entities that you can use to integrate Diligent Entities with other systems in your company. You can retrieve the following reports data available in Diligent Entities:

Companies
Data Libraries
Appointments
Individuals
Partnerships
Other Entities
Committees
Shared Addresses
Shared Contacts
Pending Events
Shareholders

The Entities Reports REST API uses standard HTTPS requests to access data and returns responses in JSON format. 
For each available report, you can make three types of requests depending on the data you want to retrieve:

You can retrieve the report with all available data.
You can retrieve the report with the data you specify.
You can retrieve the list of available data for the report.

Postman CollectionA Postman Collection is available for the Entities Reports API which enables you to jump-start working with the API. The collection contains example requests for each available endpoint.  The current Entities Reports API Postman collection is available to fork or copy from the link below.

Getting StartedTo start interacting with the Entities Reports API, you need to complete the following:

Set up access to Entities Reports API
Authenticate to Entities Reports API

LicensingThe Entities Reports API is available to clients with a professional or enterprise package. For more information, contact your Customer Success Manager (CSM).
1. Set up access to Entities Reports APIBefore you start interacting with the Reports API, you must complete the following steps required for access:  

Request site configuration for API calls
Create a user for API access
Create the access token

For detailed instructions, go to "Entities Reports API" in Entities Help Center.
1.1 Request site configuration for API calls
Each Entities site you want to make API calls to requires internal network configuration. Site configuration can take between 5 and 10 business days. 
To request API configuration for your sites, contact your Customer Success Manager and provide the web address of each site you want to configure for API calls, including test sites.
Download API values
After the sites are configured, you receive an email with a link to files containing API configuration values. For each configured site, you receive a separate API values document. 

Select View Content in the email to access the file shared with you.
In Secure File Sharing, select Download from the document menu to save the Entities API Values document to your computer.

The table below shows example values for the request URL and the API key: 



Variable Name
Value



request_URL
https://us.api.diligentcloudservices.com/entities


X-Api-Key
FXo06wgzIY8OBGxrUYmh3KZtdWRUetY33Q1NN4Ch


1.2 Create a user for API access
This section contains an overview of the steps you need to complete to create an API user. 
For detailed instructions, go to "Entities Reports API" in Entities Help Centre.

In Entities, create a new user role for API access. Use the role to configure the permissions needed for accessing the Reports API. 
You may need to adjust the user role rights or permissions. To find out which permissions are needed, send a Get metadata request to each endpoint you want to retrieve data from. The requiredAccessRight field in the response contains the information about the user permissions. 

Create a user with the new user role.


1.3 Create the API access token
An access token is a string that identifies a user and authenticates access to the Entities Reports API. 
Use the new user credentials to log in to Entities and create the access token. Access tokens can be set to expire within between 1 and 365 days. 
For detailed instructions, go to "Entities Reports API" in Entities Help Centre.
2. Authenticate to Entities Reports APIAll requests require authentication. The Entities Reports API uses the OAuth 2.0 authentication protocol. 

In the Postman collection, select Variables. 
Add the API values from the API values document you received. 
Find the access_Token variable and add the token you created in Entities as its value. 
Save your changes.

You can now make calls to Entities Reports API.  # Sending Requests
Once you have completed the authentication process, you can start sending requests.
Unique IdentifiersWhen you create a record in Diligent Entities, a quick reference is assigned to it. This quick reference is unique throughout the lifecycle of the entity. You can change the quick reference for some entities and reuse it when a new entity is created.
These types of entities have a unique identifier, called ENTITYGUID, that can't be changed: 

Companies
Individuals
Partnerships
Corporates / Other Entities

You can use these ENTITYGUID values to identify the entities when working with the Entities Reports API.
PaginationAs responses often contain many items, you can enable pagination to improve response time, reduce network traffic, and make the data set in the response easier to handle. Use the pagesize and pagenumber parameters to configure pagination in the requests you send.



Parameter
Type
Description



pagesize
Integer
The number of records on a page. Possible value range is between 1 and 200.


pagenumber
Integer
The page number of the result set. Possible value range is between 1 and 2147483647.


Requesting the API to return only specific columnsYou can use the Get data with specific column POST requests to define what columns of the report you want the API to return. To learn what columns are available in the report in question, send a Get meta data request to the corresponding endpoint. The key field contains the column identifiers in the response.

Add the keys for the columns you want to get the data for to the Columns section of the Get data with specific column POST request. If you specify no columns in the request, the API returns the default columns in the response.
Column-Level FilteringWith column-level filtering, you can apply filters to POST requests so that the API returns only the required data from the report.
To apply column-level filtering, you need to set the following two parameters in the body of the request:

FilterCombinator: This parameter sets the logic for the filters. The possible values are AND and OR.
Filters: This parameter contains the filters. Each filter consists of a column key, an operator, and a value or values that are applied to the data before the response is returned.

If you set these parameters as they are in the example request below, the response will only contain results where the company name contains Diligent AND the individual‚Äôs name starts with Tim.

FilterCombinator
The FilterCombinator sets the logic for the filters in the Filters parameter and applies to all the defined filters.



FilterCombinator Value
Operator
Description



0
AND
All filter conditions must be met. This is the default value if no combinator is specified.


1
OR
Only one of the filter conditions must be met.


Filters
Use the Filters parameter to define the filter conditions. You can add multiple filters to a request. Filters contain the following elements:

Key
Operator
PrimaryValue
SecondaryValue

Whether the PrimaryValue and SecondaryValue elements are required depends on the operator type.

Key
The identifier of the column the filter applies to.
You can get a list of available column keys for each report by sending a request to the Get meta data endpoint. For example, to find out about the available keys for the companies report, send a request to the /reports/companies/meta endpoint.
Operator
The operator to be applied to the filter.
The available operators depend on the type of column being filtered. You can learn about the column types by sending a request to the Get meta data endpoint.



Column Type
Valid Operator Types



Text
contains, notcontains, startswith, endswith, equal, notequal, isnull, isnotnull


Date, Long & Double
greaterthan, greaterthanorequal, lessthan, lessthanorequal, between, isnull, isnotnull, equal, notequal


Bool
istrue, isfalse


PrimaryValue and SecondaryValue
PrimaryValue and SecondaryValue elements are used to set the search terms required for the filter. PrimaryValue and SecondaryValue elements are not always required and depend on the operator type. The table below provides details on the required PrimaryValue and SecondaryValue elements for each operator type.



Operator Type
PrimaryValue
SecondaryValue



contains
Required
Not required


notcontains
Required
Not required


startswith
Required
Not required


endswith
Required
Not required


equal
Required
Not required


notequal
Required
Not required


isnull
Not required
Not required


isnotnull
Not required
Not required


greaterthan
Required
Not required


greaterthanorequal
Required
Not required


lessthan
Required
Not required


lessthanorequal
Required
Not required


between
Required
Required


istrue
Not required
Not required


isfalse
Not required
Not required


Responses and ErrorsThe Entities Reports APIs uses standard HTTP response codes to indicate the success or failure of a request. The following table lists some common responses that are returned when sending requests.



Code
Status
Description



200
OK
The request succeeded.


400
Bad Request
The request could not be understood by the server. The response body contains more details.


401
Unauthorized
The request requires authentication or the supplied authorization credentials have been refused.


403
Forbidden
Access to the resource is forbidden.


429
Too Many Requests
Request rate limit has been reached.


Get Data ResponseEach Get data response contains the parameters listed in the table below.



Field
Type
Description



Count
Integer
The number of available records.


reportHeaders
Array
A list of the columns available in the report.


rows
Array
Each row contains the following attributes:




- Fields: The values of the columns in the report in the same order as the columns are listed in the reportHeaders element.




-	Addresses: A list of any associated addresses with the following attributes: Full Address, Address Type and Description.




Note: Addresses are only returned if an address is available for the record. A record can contain multiple addresses.



Meta ResponseEach Get meta data response contains the parameters listed in the table below.



Field
Type
Notes



key
String
The identifier of the column.


section
String
Section


name
String
The display name of the data attribute.


description
String
The description of the data attribute.


type
String
The attribute data type such as text, date, bool and so on.


requiredAccessRight
List of Strings
The user role rights required to access the data in the column.

postCreate a new groupgetGet group informationpatchUpdate group informationScheduled UsersgetGet scheduled usersScheduled ProjectsgetGet scheduled projectsScheduled HoursgetGet scheduled hoursExtractpostCreate extraction requestgetGet extract informationStrategygetGet riskspostCreate a riskgetGet a riskpatchUpdate a riskdelDelete a riskgetGet risk assurancespostCreate a risk assurance linkgetGet a risk assurancedelDelete a risk assurance linkgetGet risk commentspostCreate a risk commentgetGet a risk commentdelDelete a risk commentgetGet risk objectivespostCreate a risk objective linkgetGet a risk objectivedelDelete a risk objective linkgetGet risk segmentsgetGet a risk segmentpatchUpdate a risk segmentgetGet risk metricspostCreate a risk metric linkgetGet a risk metricpatchUpdate a risk metricdelDelete a risk metric linkgetGet risk tagspostCreate a risk tag linkdelDelete a risk tag linkgetGet objectivespostCreate an objectivegetGet an objectivepatchUpdate an objectivedelDelete an objectivegetGet segmentspostCreate a segmentgetGet a segmentpatchUpdate a segmentdelDelete a segmentgetGet custom attributespostCreate a custom attributegetGet a custom attributepatchUpdate a custom attributedelDelete a custom attributegetGet risk status columnsgetGet a risk status columngetGet scoring factorspostCreate a scoring factorgetGet a scoring factorpatchUpdate a scoring factordelDelete a scoring factorgetGet tagspostCreate a taggetGet a tagpatchUpdate a TagdelDelete a taggetGet usersgetGet a userpatchUpdate a user roleAPI docs by RedoclyHighBond API Reference (1.1.0)Download OpenAPI specification:DownloadWelcome to the API documentation for HighBond.IntroductionThe HighBond API is the developer interface for the HighBond platform.You can use it to automate interactions with HighBond,
build reporting, and integrate HighBond with other systems in your company.This introduction contains information you should
know before you get started.The HighBond API is organized around REST and is built on the
JSON API v1.0 specification.Warning ‚Äî
This API interacts with your company's live data.It gives you the power to delete important data that your
company needs.Carefully consider the consequences of your actions when using this API.If you are not sure, contact the
person or group who administers HighBond in your company.Permissions
Users can generate and manage API tokens in their user profiles in HighBond.Because these tokens are tied to users, not companies, your permissions in the API are the same as your permissions in HighBond.Note ‚Äî
You must be a System Admin in at least one HighBond instance to access the API.If you leave your company and your HighBond user account is deleted, your application will break.Before getting started, consider the long-term requirements of your application.You may wish to create a system account in HighBond and build your application from that, but verify that your company's security policies permit accounts that aren't tied to particular people.HighBond uses the OAuth 2.0 authorization framework to control access to the API.Apps
Apps are components in HighBond that provide specific functionality.You can use this API to interact with data in the apps you have access to.The apps available to you depend on the edition of HighBond (standard or premium) in use, and whether or not your company has purchased any add-on apps.For more information, see Subscriptions, editions, and capabilities.Rate limitations
The API safeguards against bursts of usage to help maximize its stability.For most endpoints, you cannot make more than 6 requests per second.","textTemplate":"","metadataSeparator":"
","type":"TEXT","hash":"TB/24+SQvS0yuIUAalC8jx7mvAVRdXQY2orxuBzEiAc="}

7044dca8-c3a9-4076-91a1-e7df55cde785.__data__:
{"id_":"7044dca8-c3a9-4076-91a1-e7df55cde785","metadata":{"url":"https://developer.diligent.com/api/highbond"},"excludedEmbedMetadataKeys":[],"excludedLlmMetadataKeys":[],"relationships":{"SOURCE":{"nodeId":"93ea0459-06e3-4d13-a5a7-e2672baf0b21","metadata":{"url":"https://developer.diligent.com/api/highbond"},"hash":"6yno4se1V6uAQaWlHOViC3so7O9n+nKYbRw39cuyx1k="},"PREVIOUS":{"nodeId":"98230cef-4a28-496e-9eff-5a97d27c0736","metadata":{"url":"https://developer.diligent.com/api/highbond"},"hash":"IQRblXt+E6M1oBDHpO4oETEGVbChmo/G5Iyt40PYYZs="},"NEXT":{"nodeId":"f5fbf962-8645-4b4d-bbe3-81f7abef167e","metadata":{},"hash":"NyyIBNV5nOTcatj8AXUFLUyBw7n1N+pXHGDXk2DoWxs="}},"text":"If you leave your company and your HighBond user account is deleted, your application will break.Before getting started, consider the long-term requirements of your application.You may wish to create a system account in HighBond and build your application from that, but verify that your company's security policies permit accounts that aren't tied to particular people.HighBond uses the OAuth 2.0 authorization framework to control access to the API.Apps
Apps are components in HighBond that provide specific functionality.You can use this API to interact with data in the apps you have access to.The apps available to you depend on the edition of HighBond (standard or premium) in use, and whether or not your company has purchased any add-on apps.For more information, see Subscriptions, editions, and capabilities.Rate limitations
The API safeguards against bursts of usage to help maximize its stability.For most endpoints, you cannot make more than 6 requests per second.The following endpoints have a stricter rate limitation of 3 requests per minute:

Groups
Users

Treat these limits as a maximum and avoid making unnecessary requests to the API.If you make too many requests, the API responds with a 429 "Too many requests" status.Getting startedTo start interacting with your HighBond organization via the API, you need a few things:

An authentication token from your HighBond instance
The correct region URL for your HighBond instance
Information about the HighBond instance and resource IDs you want to interact with

If you need assistance with any of these, contact a HighBond administrator at your company, or email support@wegalvanize.com.Authentication
All requests require authentication.To authenticate, use Launchpad to create a HighBond API (bearer) token for your account.The token is a string that authenticates you
and allows you to securely access the HighBond API.For help creating a token, see Creating and managing access tokens.Once you have created your token, you can provide it in the header of your request:
Authorization: Bearer <TOKEN>


Important ‚Äî
If you do not authenticate yourself, the API fails. The API responds to authentication failures with a 401 "Bad credentials" status.

bearerTokenHighBond offers the industry-standard OAuth 2.0 flow for connecting to the HighBond platform. OAuth 2.0 provides a
safe and secure way to access data, while protecting your account credentials.
Security Scheme Type: HTTPHTTP Authorization Scheme: bearerBearer format: oauth2Token security
HighBond uses the Authorization Code workflow to generate tokens.
To enable continuous access to the API, and to provide full ownership and accountability to users, Galvanize does not impose an expiration date
on the token. You can delete a token in
Launchpad when you no longer need access to the API.

Important ‚Äî
Your access token provides many privileges, so keep it secure and private. Galvanize recommends that you encrypt your
machine to securely store the token. Avoid sharing your token in publicly accessible areas such GitHub or within client-side code.

API regions
The HighBond service is provided from different regions in order to give customers options for where your data is stored, and to enable you to
comply with data privacy location requirements.
Your request URL must include one of the following region codes, based on where your HighBond instance resides:

United States ‚Äî https://apis-us.highbond.com
Canada ‚Äî https://apis-ca.highbond.com
Europe ‚Äî https://apis-eu.highbond.com
Asia ‚Äî https://apis-ap.highbond.com
Australia ‚Äî https://apis-au.highbond.com
Africa ‚Äî https://apis-af.highbond.com
South America ‚Äî https://apis-sa.highbond.com
Japan ‚Äî https://apis-jp.highbond.com

Additionally, for government clients, there are two government "regions":

Gov (US federal) ‚Äî https://apis.highbond-gov.com
SLED (state, local, and education; non-federal) ‚Äî https://apis.highbond-gov2.com


Important ‚Äî
All API requests must be made over HTTPS. Calls over HTTP respond with the 301 "Moved Permanently" status.

HighBond instance and resource IDs
Requests require a HighBond instance ID and the ID of the resource you are interacting with. These IDs are numeric keys that uniquely
identify the HighBond instance and every resource in that instance.
The easiest way to get your HighBond instance ID is to log in to HighBond and take the ID from the URL:
https://accounts.highbond.com/orgs/12345

To obtain IDs for resources like collections, analyses, tables, and robots, you can navigate to the item you want to reference, and take the IDs from the URL.
For example, this URL shows a collection ID:
https://example-company.results.highbond.com/projects/55843","textTemplate":"","metadataSeparator":"
","type":"TEXT","hash":"3NeOo5wivHfQxUUc6uOEekN4rmUz3RtUlzbWBgyvIF4="}

f5fbf962-8645-4b4d-bbe3-81f7abef167e.__data__:
{"id_":"f5fbf962-8645-4b4d-bbe3-81f7abef167e","metadata":{"url":"https://developer.diligent.com/api/highbond"},"excludedEmbedMetadataKeys":[],"excludedLlmMetadataKeys":[],"relationships":{"SOURCE":{"nodeId":"93ea0459-06e3-4d13-a5a7-e2672baf0b21","metadata":{"url":"https://developer.diligent.com/api/highbond"},"hash":"6yno4se1V6uAQaWlHOViC3so7O9n+nKYbRw39cuyx1k="},"PREVIOUS":{"nodeId":"7044dca8-c3a9-4076-91a1-e7df55cde785","metadata":{"url":"https://developer.diligent.com/api/highbond"},"hash":"fNhiihVof0LbncU8uF0teRdPVjQ8rOoY+VqqQLBiJhE="},"NEXT":{"nodeId":"4ccf3685-c0d3-4252-99fb-fcde9c64747f","metadata":{},"hash":"sCGNP2UD0y0nvxJOReU2zBkKnfTLC867Bz8bbku/O+Y="}},"text":"Important ‚Äî
All API requests must be made over HTTPS. Calls over HTTP respond with the 301 "Moved Permanently" status.

HighBond instance and resource IDs
Requests require a HighBond instance ID and the ID of the resource you are interacting with. These IDs are numeric keys that uniquely
identify the HighBond instance and every resource in that instance.
The easiest way to get your HighBond instance ID is to log in to HighBond and take the ID from the URL:
https://accounts.highbond.com/orgs/12345

To obtain IDs for resources like collections, analyses, tables, and robots, you can navigate to the item you want to reference, and take the IDs from the URL.
For example, this URL shows a collection ID:
https://example-company.results.highbond.com/projects/55843Tip ‚Äî
The GET methods in this API also return IDs that you can use to identify resources you can act on.Making requestsOnce you have all the information you need, you can start making requests in an API client of your choice.HTTP methods
The API uses the appropriate HTTP method for each action:

GET ‚Äî used for retrieving resources
POST ‚Äî used for creating resources
PUT / PATCH ‚Äî used for updating resources
DELETE ‚Äî used for deleting resources

Content type
Always specify the Content-Type of your request in the header.Supported content types are:

JSON API
JSON (for backwards compatibility)

Content-Type: application/vnd.api+json
Content-Type: application/json

A complete Get a table request using curl would look like this:
curl -H "Authorization: Bearer XYZ" -H "Content-Type: application/vnd.api+json" https://apis-us.highbond.com/v1/orgs/11594/tables/388930

Requesting the API to return only specific fields
For certain resources, such as control tests, you can request the API to return only specific fields using the fields query parameter.Sparse fieldsets are
helpful for limiting your responses to only the data you require.Note ‚Äî
The type argument must specify the resource you want to retrieve.The value of the fields parameter must be a comma-delimited list that specifies
the name of the field(s) to be returned.Avoid whitespace before or after each comma.fields[type]=field_name1,field_name2,fieldname3

A complete Get a control test request that only returns the assigned_user, control, and testing_round_number fields would look like this:
curl -H "Authorization: Bearer XYZ" -H "Content-Type: application/vnd.api+json" https://apis-us.highbond.com/v1/orgs/12345/control_tests/105?fields[control_tests]=assigned_user,control,testing_round_number

Requesting the API to return related resources
To reduce the number of requests, you may use the include query parameter to return related resources in the response along with the requested primary resources.Such responses are called "compound documents".Accepted values for the include parameter are documented in the Query Parameters section of each API method.Note ‚Äî
The include parameter must be a comma-delimited list that specifies
the name of the relationship(s) or nested relationship(s) to be returned.Avoid whitespace before or after each comma.Example - requesting a relationship and a nested relationship
include=control,control.objective

A complete Get a control test request that returns the control relationship, and control.objective nested relationship would look like this:
curl -H "Authorization: Bearer XYZ" -H "Content-Type: application/vnd.api+json" https://apis.highbond.com/v1/orgs/12345/control_tests/105?include=control,control.objective

Blank fields
Blank fields are included in all response schemas as "" or null instead of being omitted.Time zones
All timestamps are returned in ISO 8601 format: YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ.Some requests that create new data, such as creating a robot task's schedule, allow you to provide time zone information.For API requests that allow for a timestamp to be specified, you must explicitly provide an ISO 8601 timestamp with time zone information."starts_at": "2019-03-21T16:25:00.478Z",
"starts_at_timezone": "America/Los_Angeles",

Rich text fields
Some requests and responses contain rich text fields that include HTML tags.These are typically description fields.If you need to format text,
the best approach is to upload your raw data first and apply formatting later in the user interface.Note ‚Äî
Images that exist in rich text fields are returned in responses, but they are not rendered.You cannot upload new images to rich text fields using the API.User identifiers
A unique identifier (UID) is an alphanumeric string that is associated with a user in HighBond.","textTemplate":"","metadataSeparator":"
","type":"TEXT","hash":"cJycq8cqsZDqPq0z4538wdZT5jOlF8CVBzExPbJYDC4="}

4ccf3685-c0d3-4252-99fb-fcde9c64747f.__data__:
{"id_":"4ccf3685-c0d3-4252-99fb-fcde9c64747f","metadata":{"url":"https://developer.diligent.com/api/highbond"},"excludedEmbedMetadataKeys":[],"excludedLlmMetadataKeys":[],"relationships":{"SOURCE":{"nodeId":"93ea0459-06e3-4d13-a5a7-e2672baf0b21","metadata":{"url":"https://developer.diligent.com/api/highbond"},"hash":"6yno4se1V6uAQaWlHOViC3so7O9n+nKYbRw39cuyx1k="},"PREVIOUS":{"nodeId":"f5fbf962-8645-4b4d-bbe3-81f7abef167e","metadata":{"url":"https://developer.diligent.com/api/highbond"},"hash":"NyyIBNV5nOTcatj8AXUFLUyBw7n1N+pXHGDXk2DoWxs="},"NEXT":{"nodeId":"d493cce7-9783-459e-b4e2-812d9b2e400f","metadata":{},"hash":"bVbCUCd/EKSZSQ/EEeT+iIlFB+qH0qxSD1clFswqE28="}},"text":"Some requests that create new data, such as creating a robot task's schedule, allow you to provide time zone information.For API requests that allow for a timestamp to be specified, you must explicitly provide an ISO 8601 timestamp with time zone information."starts_at": "2019-03-21T16:25:00.478Z",
"starts_at_timezone": "America/Los_Angeles",

Rich text fields
Some requests and responses contain rich text fields that include HTML tags.These are typically description fields.If you need to format text,
the best approach is to upload your raw data first and apply formatting later in the user interface.Note ‚Äî
Images that exist in rich text fields are returned in responses, but they are not rendered.You cannot upload new images to rich text fields using the API.User identifiers
A unique identifier (UID) is an alphanumeric string that is associated with a user in HighBond.UIDs make it possible to address users,
so that they can be accessed and interacted with using the API.Some requests that allow you to assign items to users, such as creating an objective,
require you to specify a user's UID.To obtain a user's UID:

Sign in to HighBond.If your company uses more than one instance in HighBond, make sure the appropriate instance is active.Select Options > Users (#).Navigate to the appropriate user and click the user's name.In the User Details side panel, copy the UID to your clipboard.Once you have copied the UID, you can specify it in your request.Pagination
When a response consists of a large number of items, the API breaks it into separate pages for performance reasons.You can control the way the API paginates your results by specifying how many items you want to have per page, and which page you want the API to return.For example, if you request a list of controls, the request could look like this: {protocol}://{server}/v1/orgs/{org_id}/objectives/{objective_id}/controls?page[size]=25&page[number]=Mg==
Where:

page[size]=25 specifies that there should be 25 items per page.Different endpoints have different default values and maximum numbers of values you can have per page.page[number]=Mg== specifies that the API should return the second page of results (the 26th through 50th items that match the request).Note ‚Äî
 In most cases, page numbers must be encoded in Base64.In this example, Mg== is the Base64 encoded value for 2.Additionally, responses include the links parameter, which provides URLs for the prev and next attributes (or null values if all of the items are on one page).Those URLs include the above parameters, so you can paste them into subsequent requests if needed.ErrorsHighBond uses standard HTTP response codes
to indicate the success or failure of a request.The range of a code indicates information about why it succeeded or failed:

2xx range ‚Äî Success
4xx range ‚Äî Error given the information provided
5xx range ‚Äî Server failed to fulfil a valid request

Some common errors that occur when making requests include:

400 Bad request ‚Äî When a parameter is missing (such as the org_id or resource id), when more
than one unique resource is specified in the request, or when a specified data type is incompatible with the endpoint
401 Bad credentials ‚Äî When there is an authentication error
403 Forbidden ‚Äî When there is an authorization problem based on your role in a HighBond app or subscription
404 Not found ‚Äî When there is a problem on the client side due to an incorrect URL or resource deletion
415 Unsupported media type ‚Äî When the Content-Type specified is unsupported
422 Unprocessable entity ‚Äî When a required attribute is missing (such as the name of a resource), or when a conflict occurs
(such as a script activation conflict)

VersioningAll API endpoints use a version number in the path.As can be seen in the examples, /v1/ specifies version 1 of the API.Over time, the API will evolve.New API versions will be introduced and existing versions may be updated.Some API updates are considered a breaking change, requiring a new version of the API to be introduced.An example of a breaking
change is fields being changed or removed.By introducing a new version, API consumers can safely continue to use prior API versions.The other type of API update is a non-breaking change.You should expect non-breaking change updates to existing API versions.An example of a non-breaking change is adding a field to a response object.Non-breaking changes are additive.While they do
change the response body, they should not impact the API consumer.Robots AgentsA Robots Agent is the on-premise or cloud-based Robots component that uses the Analytics script engine to run scripts against data.Learn more about the Robots Agent.","textTemplate":"","metadataSeparator":"
","type":"TEXT","hash":"6poK8YkhwiZrWrlbdblA7SLmTUf63G2C+VPzd3hVOWo="}

event reports, or as follow-up mechanisms when remediating records.Your organization can have a maximum of 14,000 questionnaires and each questionnaire can hold a maximum of 900 questions, including page breaks and sections.Learn more about questionnaires.Questionnaires consist of a series of question and layout components.Please use the dedicated endpoints to manage these components:

Question Type
Numeric Scale Question
Simple Question:
Short Answer
Paragraph
Numeric
Date
Email
Attachment
Digital Signature


Choice Question
Single Choice
Dropdown
Multiple Choice




Layout Type
Page Break
Section




Note:

Only not archived questionnaires can be managed by this set of APIs.

73b9fd5b-1df2-49c9-8d1f-5b52fc260295.__data__:
{"id_":"73b9fd5b-1df2-49c9-8d1f-5b52fc260295","metadata":{"url":"https://developer.diligent.com/api/highbond"},"excludedEmbedMetadataKeys":[],"excludedLlmMetadataKeys":[],"relationships":{"SOURCE":{"nodeId":"93ea0459-06e3-4d13-a5a7-e2672baf0b21","metadata":{"url":"https://developer.diligent.com/api/highbond"},"hash":"6yno4se1V6uAQaWlHOViC3so7O9n+nKYbRw39cuyx1k="},"PREVIOUS":{"nodeId":"a8b39ade-6641-4d3e-9bbe-2cd001944c97","metadata":{"url":"https://developer.diligent.com/api/highbond"},"hash":"2fw30Erg49wPzpBC8P06C7tNTAoV8IY3Y6y7QHduLKA="},"NEXT":{"nodeId":"d7e88343-2987-4a5f-9fbb-cb73defacb38","metadata":{},"hash":"Pim63K0hxPJ7w/Jmgg1PG7wFdTRwVXiN3cfYcSwTMk0="}},"text":"table_idrequiredinteger  Example:  300The ID of the table.Responses200 OK.400 Bad request.401 Bad credentials.403 Forbidden.404 Not found.415 Unsupported media type.get/orgs/{org_id}/tables/{table_id}/columns{protocol}://{server}/v1/orgs/{org_id}/tables/{table_id}/columns Response samples 200400415Content typeapplication/vnd.api+jsonCopy Expand all  Collapse all {"data": [{"id": "account_number","type": "columns","attributes": {"display_name": "Account number","data_type": "character","is_primary_key": true},"relationships": {"table": {"data": {"id": "300","type": "tables"}}}}]}Table recordsRecords are rows in a table.Each record can have multiple attributes with values.Upload records data When uploading records, you need to specify column names, data types, and records data.Valid data types are character, numeric, logical, date, time, and datetime.For more information, see
Supported data types.Caution ‚Äî
Changing a column's data type can break workflows in HighBond that depend on the affected column, such as visualizations, metrics, triggers, and Results table published to Activity Center.Limitations:

You cannot upload records to Projects tables.Each table can contain a maximum of 100,000 records, 500 columns, and 256 characters per field, including blank characters.You can upload up to 100 columns at once.For instance, if you need to upload 300 columns, you can do so in batches of 100 columns three times.However, please note that the total number of columns in a table cannot exceed 500.You cannot upload more than 100kbs of records nor make multiple requests simultaneously (429 error).To upload more than 100kb of data, split your records into multiple, smaller requests that can be made in sequence.If the table contains a primary key field, the values in the field must be unique.This field is used to uniquely identify each record in the table.Authorizations:bearerTokenpath Parametersorg_idrequiredstring  Example:  1The ID of the HighBond instance.table_idrequiredinteger  Example:  300The ID of the table.Request Body schema: application/jsonrequiredThe data required to upload records.datarequiredobject The data associated with the resource.optionsobject The options associated with the resource.Responses202 Accepted.400 Bad request.401 Bad credentials.403 Forbidden.404 Not found.415 Unsupported media type.422 Unprocessable entity.post/orgs/{org_id}/tables/{table_id}/upload{protocol}://{server}/v1/orgs/{org_id}/tables/{table_id}/upload Request samples PayloadContent typeapplication/jsonCopy Expand all  Collapse all {"data": {"columns": {"field_one": "character","field_two": "character"},"records": [{"field_one": "X","field_two": "2"},{"field_one": "XYZ","field_two": "676"}]},"options": {"purge": true}} Response samples 400415422Content typeapplication/vnd.api+jsonCopy Expand all  Collapse all {"errors": [{"status": 400,"code": "parameter_missing","title": "Parameter missing","detail": "The required parameter, table_id, is missing."}]}Get records Get all the records in a table.Note:

By default, this endpoint returns a maximum of 100,000 records.Records above this limit are truncated.Use query parameters to filter and get the records you need.Parameters can be applied to any field in the table with the following data type: Character, Numeric, Date, and Datetime.You can have a maximum of 2 unique fields in a single query.You can filter records by a single value or multiple values.For multiple values, add the filter string
multiple times with an addition of array indication [] to each of filter keys.The maximum limit of the query string is 6000 characters.","textTemplate":"","metadataSeparator":"
","type":"TEXT","hash":"Ht7j8zRZwAH0vrq/CeOf8swZ1nVwdW2t5rlA5sawVWw="}

d7e88343-2987-4a5f-9fbb-cb73defacb38.__data__:
{"id_":"d7e88343-2987-4a5f-9fbb-cb73defacb38","metadata":{"url":"https://developer.diligent.com/api/highbond"},"excludedEmbedMetadataKeys":[],"excludedLlmMetadataKeys":[],"relationships":{"SOURCE":{"nodeId":"93ea0459-06e3-4d13-a5a7-e2672baf0b21","metadata":{"url":"https://developer.diligent.com/api/highbond"},"hash":"6yno4se1V6uAQaWlHOViC3so7O9n+nKYbRw39cuyx1k="},"PREVIOUS":{"nodeId":"73b9fd5b-1df2-49c9-8d1f-5b52fc260295","metadata":{"url":"https://developer.diligent.com/api/highbond"},"hash":"GbDpk7YnWQ1CUOH9lu9wdd4oGbcrdamHYwoHFfcjUKg="},"NEXT":{"nodeId":"d92c49c1-8371-4f9b-bea0-3dc568e8423a","metadata":{},"hash":"/Dsz6+tbJtc5mwoE5EH/IqNYlJFEosZGLt+ld8aIKE4="}},"text":"api+jsonCopy Expand all  Collapse all {"errors": [{"status": 400,"code": "parameter_missing","title": "Parameter missing","detail": "The required parameter, table_id, is missing."}]}Get records Get all the records in a table.Note:

By default, this endpoint returns a maximum of 100,000 records.Records above this limit are truncated.Use query parameters to filter and get the records you need.Parameters can be applied to any field in the table with the following data type: Character, Numeric, Date, and Datetime.You can have a maximum of 2 unique fields in a single query.You can filter records by a single value or multiple values.For multiple values, add the filter string
multiple times with an addition of array indication [] to each of filter keys.The maximum limit of the query string is 6000 characters.



Examples:

If you need to get records that are in "New" status:
{protocol}://{server}/v1/orgs/{org_id}/tables/{table_id}/records?filter[metadata.status]=New
If you need to get records that are in either "New" or "Open" status:
{protocol}://{server}/v1/orgs/{org_id}/tables/{table_id}/records?filter[metadata.status][]=New&filter[metadata.status][]=Open
If you need to get records that are in either "New" or "Open" status with a publish date of "2022-05-10T00:03:46Z".
{protocol}://{server}/v1/orgs/{org_id}/tables/{table_id}/records?filter[metadata.status][]=New&filter[metadata.status][]=Open&filter[metadata.publish_date]=2022-05-10T00:03:46ZAuthorizations:bearerTokenpath Parametersorg_idrequiredstring  Example:  1The ID of the HighBond instance.table_idrequiredinteger  Example:  300The ID of the table.query Parametersfilter[metadata.status][]string  Example:  filter[metadata.status][]=NewRequesting the API to return records with the specified statuses only.To filter the records for multiple values, add the filter string multiple times.For example, if you need to get records that have either "New" or "Open" status, pass the filters as follows ?filter[metadata.status][]=New&filter[metadata.status][]=Open.For more information, see Making requests
filter[metadata.assignee]string  Example:  filter[metadata.assignee]=Bob%20MarleyRequesting the API to return records with the specified assignees only.For more information, see Making requests

all active projects, archived projects, temporarily deleted projects, and frameworks associated with the project type.Each project type has an associated workflow: Workplan (procedure) or Internal Control (control).Workflows define the components available in a project
or framework.The attributes narrative_terms, control_test_terms, and test_plan_terms are not available for a Workplan (procedure) workflow.When creating a new project type, only the basic defining attributes are available.After creating the project type default customizable terms and toggles
are returned and available on PATCH requests for update.Get project types 
Deprecation notice ‚Äî
Please note that conclusion_values_true and conclusion_values_false fields will be deprecated.Consider using new conclusion_status_options_true and conclusion_status_options_false fields instead.Get all project types for an account.Authorizations:bearerTokenpath Parametersorg_idrequiredstring  Example:  1The ID of the HighBond instance.query Parametersfields[project_types]string  Example:  fields[project_types]=name,description,workflow,project_terms,certification_terms,control_terms,finding_terms,finding_retest_terms,finding_remediation_terms,control_test_terms,narrative_terms,objective_terms,planning_terms,results_terms,risk_terms,risk_control_matrix_terms,test_plan_terms,process_walkthrough_terms,walkthrough_terms,testing_round_terms,assigned_usersRequesting the API to return only the specified fields.For more information, see Making requests

project or framework structure.Creating a project type:
When creating a new project type, only the basic defining attributes are available.After creating the project type default customizable terms and toggles
are returned and available on PATCH requests for update.Copying a project type:
When copying an existing project type, you must define a source_project_type_id parameter in your request data, with its value being the ID of the
existing project type you want to copy.Do not include this if you wish to create a new project type.The attributes object must be included in the 
request data, however, it will be ignored when copying.Limitations:

There can be a maximum of 500 project types per HighBond instance.Authorizations:bearerTokenpath Parametersorg_idrequiredstring  Example:  1The ID of the HighBond instance.query Parametersfields[project_types]string  Example:  fields[project_types]=name,description,workflow,project_terms,certification_terms,control_terms,finding_terms,finding_retest_terms,finding_remediation_terms,control_test_terms,narrative_terms,objective_terms,planning_terms,results_terms,risk_terms,risk_control_matrix_terms,test_plan_terms,process_walkthrough_terms,walkthrough_terms,testing_round_terms,assigned_usersRequesting the API to return only the specified fields.For more information, see Making requests

You cannot delete the objective in the following scenarios:

if the objective is included in an existing certification program
if the objective has been checked out using
Offline Projects or the
HighBond iPad app


Caution ‚Äî
Deleting an objective also removes associated data (including risks, controls, walkthroughs, test plans, control tests, to-dos, requests, issues, actions, time entries, etc.). Once deleted, you cannot access or restore the objective.

To delete this objective, you must delete the associated certification."}]}Create objective entity link Link entity to an objective.

Note

Tagging an objective to an entity automatically tags an objective with all ancestor entities and descendant entities.
Request Get an objective with entities query param to get the whole list of entities linked to an objective.


Limitations:

You cannot tag the objective with entity if it has been checked out using
  Offline Projects or the
  HighBond iPad app.
Only 1 entity can be sent in the request payload.

Learn more about tagging items with entities.

Note -
Untagging an objective from an entity automatically untags an objective from all descendant entities.

Limitations:

You cannot untag an objective from an entity if it has been checked out using
  Offline Projects or the
  HighBond iPad app.
Inherited entity tags cannot be removed.

You cannot delete the risk in the following scenarios:

if the risk is included in an existing certification program
if the objective it belongs to has been checked out using
Offline Projects or the
HighBond iPad app


Caution ‚Äî
Deleting a risk also removes associated data (including assessment drivers, to-dos, requests, issues, actions, time entries, etc.). Once deleted, you cannot access or restore the risk.

delete/orgs/{org_id}/risks/{id}{protocol}://{server}/v1/orgs/{org_id}/risks/{id} Response samples 422Content typeapplication/vnd.api+jsonCopy Expand all  Collapse all {"errors": [{"status": 422,"code": "certification_association","detail": "This risk is associated with one or more certifications."}]}Create risk entity link Link entity to a risk.

Note

Tagging a risk to an entity automatically tags a risk with all ancestor entities and descendant entities.
Request Get a risk with entities query param to get the whole list of entities linked to a risk.


Limitations:

You cannot tag the risk with entity if the objective it belongs to has been checked out using
  Offline Projects or the
  HighBond iPad app.
Only 1 entity can be sent in the request payload.

Learn more about tagging items with entities.

Note -
Untagging a risk from an entity automatically untags a risk from all descendant entities.

Limitations:

You cannot untag a risk from an entity if the objective it belongs to has been checked out using
  Offline Projects or the
  HighBond iPad app.
Inherited entity tags cannot be removed.

Controls are organized by objectives, and can be associated with one or more risks.
The combination of identified risks and corresponding controls defines the Risk Control Matrix. Controls are also known as procedures.

Note:
Controls located in such resources can be accessed using the API:

In projects that have an "active" state

objective.Limitations:
You cannot delete the control in the following scenarios:

if the control is included in an existing certification program,
control performance schedule, or
assessment survey
if the objective it belongs to has been checked out using
Offline Projects or the
HighBond iPad app


Caution ‚Äî
Deleting a control also removes associated data (including assessment drivers, to-dos, requests, issues, actions, time entries, etc.). Once deleted, you cannot access or restore the control.

To delete this control, you must delete the associated certification."}]}Get all controls in an organization Get a list of all of the controls in an organization.

Note:
By default, this endpoint only returns controls from active projects. To fetch objects from archived projects or frameworks, do one of the following:

Specify the project or framework ID using filter[project.id]
Specify that you want results from archived projects using filter[project.state]=archive
Specify that you want results from frameworks using filter[project.state]=framework","textTemplate":"","metadataSeparator":"

Learn more about tagging items with entities. ","testing_conclusion": true,"testing_conclusion_status": "Operating Effectively","custom_attributes": [{"id": "42","term": "Custom Control Test Attribute","value": ["Custom Select Option Text"]}]},"relationships": {"control": {"data": {"id": "1","type": "controls"}},"assigned_user": {"data": {"id": "3NQ6XzAUxqJMnAQ7n4KF","type": "users"}}}}}WalkthroughsA walkthrough is a series of steps you perform to establish the reliability of controls and test the design of controls.Each control you define has a corresponding walkthrough that is used to verify that the control is designed appropriately.In a Workplan workflow project, a walkthrough is called an execute procedure.Note Only walkthroughs in projects that have an "active" state can be accessed using the API.To access walkthroughs using the API, the walkthroughs tab must be enabled in the project type associated with the project. Learn more about walkthroughs. Get organization walkthroughs Get a list of all of the walkthroughs in an organization. Note: By default, this endpoint only returns walkthroughs from active projects. To fetch objects from archived projects or frameworks, do one of the following: Specify the project or framework ID using filter[project.id] Specify that you want results from archived projects using filter[project.state]=archive Specify that you want results from frameworks using filter[project.state]=frameworkAuthorizations:bearerTokenpath Parametersorg_idrequiredstring Example: 1The ID of the HighBond instance.query Parametersfields[walkthroughs]string Example: fields[walkthroughs]=walkthrough_results,control_design,created_at,updated_at,custom_attributes,control,planned_milestone_date,actual_milestone_dateRequesting the API to return only the specified fields.For more information, see Making requests page[size]string Example: page[size]=25The number of items returned per page.Default is 50.Maximum is 100.page[number]string Example: page[number]=Mg==The Base64-encoded page number of records to return.sortstring Default: "id" Enum: "id" "walkthrough_results" "control_design" "created_at" "updated_at" Requesting the API to sort walkthroughs by the values in a given field.The walkthroughs are sorted ascending by default, but you can prefix the field name with - to sort descending (e.g., -id).You can sort walkthroughs by only one field at a time.filter[project.","textTemplate":"","metadataSeparator":" ","type":"TEXT","hash":"8CPfxHm5+tEURSlfeAN/5c6mA/8iogDnxf/ZTf3WnrA="}

Collaborators are accessible both in project and framework resources.
The collaborator section has endpoints for both individuals and groups.

Note:

Only users that have an assigned effective_role are returned in the response.
The updated_at field represents the date that the collaborator or collaborator group was last directly updated. Changes to the effective_role may occur as a result of assigning the user or group a group_role, but doing so won't update the updated_at field.Learn more about roles and permissions.Get collaborators Get all collaborators in a project or framework.Note:

contain a set of statuses that a certain item belonging to that workflow can be in.Any items in this workflow can move between certain statuses and the transition can trigger certain events which will execute their handlers.Workflow statuses represent all possible states an item of the workflow can be in.Statuses can be associated with Events to allow transition from one status to another within the same workflow.Every workflow must have exactly one \"default\" status.You can make a status the default status by setting or updating the default flag on that status.This default status cannot be deleted.List Workflows List Workflows and their metadata for an organization.Does not include relationships with other entities (statuses, events, etc).Authorizations:bearerTokenpath content.401 Bad credentials.403 Forbidden.404 Not found.delete/orgs/{org_id}/compliance_requirements/{id}{protocol}://{server}/v1/orgs/{org_id}/compliance_requirements/{id}Create a link between requirements Organizations typically need to be compliant with multiple standards and regulations that may have related or overlapping requirements.Related requirements indicate that controls implemented for one requirement should effectively address another (related) requirement.To link two requirements, you need the requirement ID for each requirement, whether the related requirement supports or overlaps the first requirement, the strength of the relationship, and whether the link should be active or not.When you create a link, that link is tracked with a unique ID, which you can use again later to update or delete that relationship.Use the related requirements feature at your discretion and risk.You are responsible to apply professional judgment to determine the appropriate procedures, tests, or controls for your own use.Learn more.Authorizations:bearerTokenpath Parametersorg_idrequiredstring  Example:  1The ID of the HighBond instance.query Strategy.A strategic risk is an effect of uncertainty on a strategic objective, with the effect having a positive or
negative deviation from what is expected.The status field is the current state of the risk on the Kanban Board,
its values can be:

assess
accepted
audit
continuously_audit
mitigated

The field strategy_custom_attributes is an array containing all the currently assigned
custom attributes for the risk.To get the definition of any custom attribute, you can use the
Get a custom attribute endpoint.To retrive the heat, score and any other hidden fields, use the fields[strategy_risks] query parameter as
described below.Authorizations:bearerTokenpath Parametersorg_idrequiredstring  Example:  1The ID of the HighBond instance.query Parametersfields[strategy_risks]string  Example:  fields[strategy_risks]=title,description,status,score,residual_score,heat,residual_heat,strategy_custom_attributes,risk_manager_risk_id,created_at,updated_atRequesting the API to return only the specified fields.For more information, see Making requests
page[size]string  Example:  page[size]=10The number of items returned per page.Default is 20.Maximum is 100.page[number]string  Example:  page[number]=Mg==The Base64-encoded page number of records to return.Responses200 OK.400 Bad request.401 Bad credentials.403 Forbidden.404 Not found.get/orgs/{org_id}/strategy_risks{protocol}://{server}/v1/orgs/{org_id}/strategy_risks Response samples 200400Content typeapplication/vnd.api+jsonCopy Expand all  Collapse all {"links": {"next": "/v1/orgs/1/strategy_risks?page[number]=Mg==","prev": null},"data": [{"id": "1","type": "strategy_risks","attributes": {"title": "Strategic Risk","description": "Risk Description","status": "audit","strategy_custom_attributes": [{"id": "42","term": "Custom Risk Attribute","value": ["First Custom Select Option Text","Second Custom Select Option Text"]}],"score": "0.0","residual_score": "0.0","heat": "0.0","residual_heat": "0.0","risk_manager_risk_id": "1","created_at": "2019-02-09T13:17:26Z","updated_at": "2019-02-09T13:17:26Z"}}]}Create a risk Create a new risk in Strategy.A strategic risk is an effect of uncertainty on a strategic objective, with the effect having a positive or
negative deviation from what is expected.The status field is the current state of the risk on the Kanban Board,
its values can be:

assess
accepted
audit
continuously_audit
mitigated

The field strategy_custom_attributes is an array containing all the currently assigned
custom attributes for the risk.To get the definition of any custom attribute, you can use the

Strategy.An operating segment is a region, business unit, division, location, or entity across which strategic risks are assessed.The organization's operating segments can be accessed with the
Segments resource.Authorizations:bearerTokenpath Parametersorg_idrequiredstring  Example:  1The ID of the HighBond instance.risk_idrequiredinteger  Example:  1The ID of the risk.query Parameterspage[size]string  Example:  page[size]=10The number of items returned per page.Default is 20.Maximum is 100.page[number]string  Example:  page[number]=Mg==The Base64-encoded page number of records to return.Responses200 OK.400 Bad request.401 Bad credentials.403 Forbidden.404 Not found.get/orgs/{org_id}/strategy_risks/{risk_id}/strategy_segments{protocol}://{server}/v1/orgs/{org_id}/strategy_risks/{risk_id}/strategy_segments Response samples 200400Content typeapplication/vnd.api+jsonCopy Expand all  Collapse all {"links": {"next": "/v1/orgs/1/strategy_risks/1/strategy_segments?page[number]=Mg==","prev": null},"data": [{"id": "101","type": "strategy_segments","attributes": {"name": "EMEA","created_at": "2019-02-09T13:17:26Z","updated_at": "2019-02-09T13:17:26Z"}}]}Get a risk segment Get information about an operating segment for the risk.The field strategy_factors lists the values of the assessed severity levels for the current segment of the risk.To get information about this factor, use the Factor
resource.To fetch the treatment data, you can specify the required fields via the fields[strategy_segments] or
fields[strategy_factors] query parameters, as described below.Authorizations:bearerTokenpath Parametersorg_idrequiredstring  Example:  1The ID of the HighBond instance.risk_idrequiredinteger  Example:  1The ID of the risk.idrequiredstring  Example:  9999The ID of the requested resource.query Parametersfields[strategy_segments]string  Example:  fields[strategy_segments]=name,score,strategy_factors,created_at,updated_atRequesting the API to return only the specified fields for the segment.For more information, see Making requests
fields[strategy_factors]string  Example:  fields[strategy_factors]=id,treatment_value,treatment_weight,treatment_factors,severity_valueRequesting the API to return only the specified fields for treatments.For more information, see Making requests

Strategy.Each organization can have a maximum of 10 user-defined attributes, which can be associated with each risk inside
the application.The field_type specifies the data type of the attribute.Its value can be one of the following:

text
rich_text
select
multiselect

The field_type multiselect and select can have multiple possible options defined.These are shown inside
the field options as an array.For all other types this field will be empty.To get a risk's custom attributes use the Risk resource
which lists all of its linked attributes and their values.is_default is a boolean value which indicates whether the attribute is created by default or not.After changing
any data of the attribute, the is_default value will be set to false.Authorizations:bearerTokenpath Parametersorg_idrequiredstring  Example:  1The ID of the HighBond instance.query Parameterspage[size]string  Example:  page[size]=10The number of items returned per page.Default is 20.Maximum is 100.page[number]string  Example:  page[number]=Mg==The Base64-encoded page number of records to return.Responses200 OK.400 Bad request.401 Bad credentials.403 Forbidden.404 Not found.get/orgs/{org_id}/strategy_custom_attributes{protocol}://{server}/v1/orgs/{org_id}/strategy_custom_attributes Response samples 200400Content typeapplication/vnd.api+jsonCopy Expand all  Collapse all {"links": {"next": "/v1/orgs/1/strategy_custom_attributes?","textTemplate":"","metadataSeparator":"

c2435890-1ea5-4d4d-97f4-c3bd06af117f.__data__:
{"id_":"c2435890-1ea5-4d4d-97f4-c3bd06af117f","metadata":{"url":"https://developer.diligent.com/api/esg"},"excludedEmbedMetadataKeys":[],"excludedLlmMetadataKeys":[],"relationships":{"SOURCE":{"nodeId":"a5bac318-40a1-4f4f-a82c-390b726e5f58","metadata":{"url":"https://developer.diligent.com/api/esg"},"hash":"YF14VwNXBdNvO+qQxmyJrbO/kNZvdpLdXdF7S+S3wdo="},"NEXT":{"nodeId":"ee8ed921-6ccb-41a3-8094-4b1b40ccfa52","metadata":{},"hash":"3gKeRHeZmIHopujrjQMEJw7J3O25Q9r0lacRUpSAGfA="}},"text":"Diligent ESG API Documentation | Diligent Developer PortalSkip to main content‚Üê Back to main menuIntroductionRoles and responsibilitiesGetting StartedLicensingRequest Diligent ESG site enablementAPI UserAuthenticationAPI regionsCreating an API keyFormatting and structuring your activity usage dataCopy the Company ID to call API endpointsSending requestsRate limitationsUnique identifiersPaginationFiltersResponses and errorsTimezonesSending requests ‚Äì use caseVersioningChangelog2023-12-17 - Initial version2024-01-16 - Additional activity data support2024-03-10 - Additional activity data support2024-09-30 - Additional activity data supportCore resourcesActivitiesgetList activitiesActivity DatapostAdd data to an electricity activitypostAdd data to employee travel activitypostAdd data to a fuel activitypostAdd data to a GHG activity datapostAdd data to a waste activity datapostAdd data to a water activity dataActivity MetadatagetList source categoriesgetList activity types relating to the source categorygetList calculation methodsgetList emission factor sources for calculation methodsAssetsgetList assetsCommongetList activity inputsgetList airportsgetList calorific valuesgetList countriesgetList currenciesgetList metering reading typesgetList activity data reference typesgetList activity scopesgetList suppliersgetList travel class typesgetList units of measureOrganizationsgetFetch organization main data by its IDSitesgetList sitesWastegetList waste disposal locationsgetList waste disposal methodsgetList waste fractionsAPI docs by RedoclyDiligent ESG - Accuvio API Download OpenAPI specification:DownloadWelcome to the API documentation for Diligent ESG.IntroductionThe Diligent ESG API is the developer interface for Diligent ESG platform.You can use the API to send activity entry (usage) data to Diligent ESG from your internal systems.This introduction contains information that you should know before you get started.Roles and responsibilitiesDiligent ESG provides the API, necessary documentation to communicate with the API, and endpoints so you can gather your data to construct the activity entry data that you will send to the Diligent ESG platform.While Diligent provides these items and information, Diligent ESG‚Äôs engagement does not extend to:

Interaction with third-party vendors: If you use third-party vendors for your integration, it is your responsibility to manage and coordinate with them.Direct involvement in your development process: Diligent ESG doesn‚Äôt directly engage in writing or maintaining the code between the API integration and your internal system.When you purchase an API license, it is the responsibility of your technical team, internal or third-party, to successfully implement and provide ongoing maintenance of this API integration.Getting StartedThe Diligent ESG API is built around REST and is built on the OpenAPI 3.0 specification.You can use the API to send activity entry (usage) data.For more information about the supported source categories, go to Changelog.Note: Diligent ESG will add further source categories over time.Caution: This API interacts with your company's live  data.It gives you the power to add important data that your company needs.Carefully consider the consequences of your actions when using this API.If you  are not sure, contact the person or group who administers Diligent ESG in your  company.To start interacting with the Diligent ESG API, you need to complete the following:

Request an API license
Request that your site be enabled for API calls
Login to Diligent ESG
Copy your company‚Äôs ID to call API endpoints
Create an API key
Format and structure your activity usage data

LicensingThe Diligent ESG API is available to clients upon request.To enquire about Diligent ESG API, contact your Customer Success Manager (CSM).Request Diligent ESG site enablementFor each Diligent ESG company, you must request that the API module is enabled.You can then create an API key that allows you to make API requests.To request that the module is enabled, contact your Customer Success Manager (CSM).API UserWe recommend you create a dedicated user in Diligent ESG
that is used solely for making API requests with the required user role rights
or permissions.For example, to request data through the List all facilities
and assets endpoint, the user must have access to facilities data.To learn more about users and user role rights, go to the Managing user access section of the Diligent ESG support site.AuthenticationAll requests require authentication.To authenticate, use Diligent ESG to create a token (API key) for your account.The token (API key) is a string that authenticates you and allows you to securely access the Diligent ESG API.After you have created your token, you can provide it in the header of your request:
Authorization: Bearer <TOKEN>
Important: If you do not authenticate yourself, the API fails.","textTemplate":"","metadataSeparator":"
","type":"TEXT","hash":"Ymt8fDB+JKAD0JsRpSFbSS4fqpL3Ei5IXMgGyLOmxwY="}

ee8ed921-6ccb-41a3-8094-4b1b40ccfa52.__data__:
{"id_":"ee8ed921-6ccb-41a3-8094-4b1b40ccfa52","metadata":{"url":"https://developer.diligent.com/api/esg"},"excludedEmbedMetadataKeys":[],"excludedLlmMetadataKeys":[],"relationships":{"SOURCE":{"nodeId":"a5bac318-40a1-4f4f-a82c-390b726e5f58","metadata":{"url":"https://developer.diligent.com/api/esg"},"hash":"YF14VwNXBdNvO+qQxmyJrbO/kNZvdpLdXdF7S+S3wdo="},"PREVIOUS":{"nodeId":"c2435890-1ea5-4d4d-97f4-c3bd06af117f","metadata":{"url":"https://developer.diligent.com/api/esg"},"hash":"Ymt8fDB+JKAD0JsRpSFbSS4fqpL3Ei5IXMgGyLOmxwY="},"NEXT":{"nodeId":"2921f425-97d9-44e9-a3ed-7144929d0501","metadata":{},"hash":"z+cwj2ln6m6j8v7SVCDfPQBZfafGuAUibvwqLuT+zsQ="}},"text":"To request that the module is enabled, contact your Customer Success Manager (CSM).API UserWe recommend you create a dedicated user in Diligent ESG
that is used solely for making API requests with the required user role rights
or permissions.For example, to request data through the List all facilities
and assets endpoint, the user must have access to facilities data.To learn more about users and user role rights, go to the Managing user access section of the Diligent ESG support site.AuthenticationAll requests require authentication.To authenticate, use Diligent ESG to create a token (API key) for your account.The token (API key) is a string that authenticates you and allows you to securely access the Diligent ESG API.After you have created your token, you can provide it in the header of your request:
Authorization: Bearer <TOKEN>
Important: If you do not authenticate yourself, the API fails.The API responds to authentication failures with a 401 "Bad credentials" status.API regionsThe Diligent ESG service is provided from different regions in order to give customers options for where your data is stored,  and to enable you to comply with data privacy location requirements.Your request URL must include one of the following region codes,  based on where your Diligent ESG instance resides:

Ireland - https://eco-api.accuvio.com

Note: Additional regions, US and Europe (Frankfurt) will be added in August 2024.Important: All API requests must be made over HTTPS.Calls over HTTP respond with the 301 "Moved Permanently" status.Creating an API keyThe API key programmatically authenticates your identity to Diligent ESG.This allows applications to perform specific actions defined by the read, write, or admin permissions granted.If you need an API key for yourself, go to Creating an API key for your profile.If you are a regular user, request the administrator on the system to create an API key using Creating an API key for another user.An API key is created which you can copy to use to authenticate your identity to Diligent ESG.Important: You can only view the API key once after creation so immediately copy it to a safe location.Otherwise, you must delete the key and recreate it.Formatting and structuring your activity usage dataYou need to format and structure your activity usage data to
match the Diligent ESG schema.You can use the help outlined in the endpoints.Note: If you require further assistance matching the Diligent ESG schema, you can contact support@accuvio.com.Copy the Company ID to call API endpointsYou need the company's ID to call the API endpoints.Use this ID to get and send the data that you need for your business.For further information about copying the company's ID, go to Copying your company‚Äôs ID.Sending requestsAfter you have completed the authentication process, you can start sending requests.Important: You  can only make one request per activity usage  data, you  cannot bulk send usage data.Rate limitationsThe API safeguards against bursts of usage to help maximize  its stability.If you make too many requests, the API responds with a 429 "Too  many requests" status.Unique identifiersWhen you create a record in Diligent ESG, a unique quick  reference is assigned to it.This quick reference is unique throughout the  lifecycle of the item.PaginationAs responses often contain many items, you can enable pagination to improve response time, reduce network traffic, and make the data set in the response easier to handle.Use the page_size and page ;parameters to configure pagination in the requests you send.Additionally, responses include the links parameter, which provides the following URI's first_page, next_page, prev_page and last_page (or null values for next_page and prev_page if all the items are on one page) so you can use them for subsequent requests.



Parameter
Type
Description



page_size
Integer
The number of records on a page. Possible value range is between 1 and 100. The default value is 100.


page
Integer
The page number of the result set. Possible value range is between 1 and 2147483647. The default value is 1.


first_page
URI
The link to the first page.


next_page
URI
The link to the next page.


prev_page
URI
The link to the previous page.


last_page
URI
The link to the last page.","textTemplate":"","metadataSeparator":"
","type":"TEXT","hash":"519N0qA8yJs9QquJHm4Ck3l0qLOwNeeS6zQy4VU7lhA="}

last_page
URI
The link to the last page.


FiltersUse the Filters parameter to define the filter conditions.
You can add multiple filters to a request. All GET queries support filtering and follow these two rules:

Text is not case-sensitive: Text must be an exact match but does not have to exactly match the case, upper or lower.
Multiple filters apply AND connection: If you combine multiple filters, then the API uses an AND connection between them. Diligent ESG only shows results when both filters are matched.

Responses and errorsThe Diligent ESG API uses standard HTTP response codes to  indicate the success or failure of a request. The following table lists some common responses that are returned when sending requests.



Code
Status
Description



200
OK
The request succeeded.


400
Bad Request
The request could not be understood by the server. The response body contains more details.


401
Unauthorized
The request requires authentication or the supplied authorization credentials have been refused.


403
Forbidden
Access to the resource is forbidden.


409
Conflict
Module is not active.


429
Too Many Requests
Request rate limit has been reached. You can try again in a few seconds using exponential backoff.


5xx
Server error
Server failed to fulfil a valid request. You can try again in a few seconds using exponential backoff.


TimezonesDiligent ESG operates exclusively in the Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) time zone. All dates and times recorded within the system are stored and displayed in UTC by default. All data that you upload using the API will use UTC rather than your local time zone for dates and times.
Sending requests ‚Äì use caseYou want to send 20kWh of used electricity (Scope 2) for Building A for a given period to Accuvio. To do this, you need to get the Activity ID and any other data from Diligent ESG to construct the payload and send it using the API. 


Use the following query to identify your company‚Äôs assets: 
GET/v1/¬´company_id¬ª/assetsNote: Replace  with your company‚Äôs ID. For further information, go to Copy the Company ID to call API endpoints

Use the following query to filter your company‚Äôs assets and receive your company‚Äôs activity IDs: 
GET/v1/¬´company_id>/activities 
Note: You require activity IDs to push activity data to the system. 

Use the following query to request your company‚Äôs reference type IDs: 
GET/v1/¬´company_id¬ª/common/reference_types 

Use the following query to request your company‚Äôs meter reading type IDs: 
GET/v1/¬´company_id¬ª/common/meter_reading_types 

Use the following query to request your company‚Äôs unit IDs: 
GET/v1/¬´company_id¬ª/common/units 

Use the following query to request your company‚Äôs currency IDs: 
GET/v1/¬´company_id¬ª/common/currencies 

Use the following query to request your company‚Äôs supplier IDs: 
GET/v1/¬´company_id¬ª/common/suppliers 

Use the following query to push your company‚Äôs activity data to the system: 
POST/v1/¬´company_id¬ª/electricity/activity_data 
Note: Include the activity IDs that you received in Step 2 in the Request body.","textTemplate":"","metadataSeparator":"

As can be seen in the examples, /v1/ specifies version 1 of the API. 
Over time, the API will evolve. New API versions will be introduced and existing versions may be updated. 
Some API updates are considered a breaking change, requiring a new version of the API to be introduced. An example of a breaking change is fields being changed or removed. By introducing a new version, API consumers can safely continue to use prior API versions. 
The other type of API update is a non-breaking change. You should expect non-breaking change updates to existing API versions. An example of a non-breaking change is adding a field to a response object. Non-breaking changes are additive. While they do change the response body, they should not impact the API consumer. 
For further information about the current version and the recent version updates, go to Change Log.

columnsModelsData Library Report ModelReport ModelAPI docs by RedoclyEntities Reports API (1.0.1)Download OpenAPI specification:DownloadIntroductionThe Entities Reports API is the developer interface for Diligent Entities that you can use to integrate Diligent Entities with other systems in your company. You can retrieve the following reports data available in Diligent Entities:

Companies
Data Libraries
Appointments
Individuals
Partnerships
Other Entities
Committees
Shared Addresses
Shared Contacts
Pending Events
Shareholders

The Entities Reports REST API uses standard HTTPS requests to access data and returns responses in JSON format. 
For each available report, you can make three types of requests depending on the data you want to retrieve:

You can retrieve the report with all available data.
You can retrieve the report with the data you specify.
You can retrieve the list of available data for the report.

Postman CollectionA Postman Collection is available for the Entities Reports API which enables you to jump-start working with the API. The collection contains example requests for each available endpoint.  The current Entities Reports API Postman collection is available to fork or copy from the link below.

Getting StartedTo start interacting with the Entities Reports API, you need to complete the following:

Set up access to Entities Reports API
Authenticate to Entities Reports API

LicensingThe Entities Reports API is available to clients with a professional or enterprise package. For more information, contact your Customer Success Manager (CSM).
1. Set up access to Entities Reports APIBefore you start interacting with the Reports API, you must complete the following steps required for access:  

Request site configuration for API calls
Create a user for API access
Create the access token

For detailed instructions, go to "Entities Reports API" in Entities Help Center.
1.1 Request site configuration for API calls
Each Entities site you want to make API calls to requires internal network configuration. Site configuration can take between 5 and 10 business days. 
To request API configuration for your sites, contact your Customer Success Manager and provide the web address of each site you want to configure for API calls, including test sites.
Download API values
After the sites are configured, you receive an email with a link to files containing API configuration values. For each configured site, you receive a separate API values document. 

Select View Content in the email to access the file shared with you.
In Secure File Sharing, select Download from the document menu to save the Entities API Values document to your computer.

The table below shows example values for the request URL and the API key: 



Variable Name
Value



request_URL
https://us.api.diligentcloudservices.com/entities

1.2 Create a user for API access
This section contains an overview of the steps you need to complete to create an API user. 
For detailed instructions, go to "Entities Reports API" in Entities Help Centre.

In Entities, create a new user role for API access. Use the role to configure the permissions needed for accessing the Reports API. 
You may need to adjust the user role rights or permissions. To find out which permissions are needed, send a Get metadata request to each endpoint you want to retrieve data from. The requiredAccessRight field in the response contains the information about the user permissions. 

Create a user with the new user role.


1.3 Create the API access token
An access token is a string that identifies a user and authenticates access to the Entities Reports API. 
Use the new user credentials to log in to Entities and create the access token. Access tokens can be set to expire within between 1 and 365 days. 
For detailed instructions, go to "Entities Reports API" in Entities Help Centre.
2. Authenticate to Entities Reports APIAll requests require authentication. The Entities Reports API uses the OAuth 2.0 authentication protocol. 

In the Postman collection, select Variables. 
Add the API values from the API values document you received. 
Find the access_Token variable and add the token you created in Entities as its value. 
Save your changes.

You can now make calls to Entities Reports API.  # Sending Requests
Once you have completed the authentication process, you can start sending requests.
Unique IdentifiersWhen you create a record in Diligent Entities, a quick reference is assigned to it. This quick reference is unique throughout the lifecycle of the entity. You can change the quick reference for some entities and reuse it when a new entity is created.
These types of entities have a unique identifier, called ENTITYGUID, that can't be changed: 

Companies
Individuals
Partnerships
Corporates / Other Entities

You can use these ENTITYGUID values to identify the entities when working with the Entities Reports API.
PaginationAs responses often contain many items, you can enable pagination to improve response time, reduce network traffic, and make the data set in the response easier to handle. Use the pagesize and pagenumber parameters to configure pagination in the requests you send.



Parameter
Type
Description



pagesize
Integer
The number of records on a page. Possible value range is between 1 and 200.


pagenumber
Integer
The page number of the result set. Possible value range is between 1 and 2147483647.


Requesting the API to return only specific columnsYou can use the Get data with specific column POST requests to define what columns of the report you want the API to return. To learn what columns are available in the report in question, send a Get meta data request to the corresponding endpoint. The key field contains the column identifiers in the response.

Add the keys for the columns you want to get the data for to the Columns section of the Get data with specific column POST request. If you specify no columns in the request, the API returns the default columns in the response.
Column-Level FilteringWith column-level filtering, you can apply filters to POST requests so that the API returns only the required data from the report.
To apply column-level filtering, you need to set the following two parameters in the body of the request:

FilterCombinator: This parameter sets the logic for the filters. The possible values are AND and OR.
Filters: This parameter contains the filters. Each filter consists of a column key, an operator, and a value or values that are applied to the data before the response is returned.

If you set these parameters as they are in the example request below, the response will only contain results where the company name contains Diligent AND the individual‚Äôs name starts with Tim.

FilterCombinator
The FilterCombinator sets the logic for the filters in the Filters parameter and applies to all the defined filters.



FilterCombinator Value
Operator
Description



0
AND
All filter conditions must be met. This is the default value if no combinator is specified.


1
OR
Only one of the filter conditions must be met.","textTemplate":"","startCharIdx":4704,"endCharIdx":9088,"metadataSeparator":"
